newsitem.title: ECUADOR: New Ecuador's president is a skilful negotiator.
newsitem.headline: New Ecuador's president is a skilful negotiator.

text.p: Fabian Alarcon, voted Ecuador's 41st president on Tuesday, is a politician known for sharp negotiating skills.

Congress voted by an overwhelming 57-2 majority, with five abstentions and one blank vote, to appoint him interim president, for the second time in a week. He is set to rule until Aug. 10, 1998, and hand over to a president to be elected early next year.
The 49-year-old head of Congress was not long ago a staunch ally of ousted leader Abdala Bucaram. He was even considered as Bucaram's possible running mate for last year's general elections.
Alarcon accompanied Bucaram during the campaign, standing firmly by his side while the eccentric populist insulted political opponents or belted out pop tunes.
Yet, he did not hesitate last week to urge 4,000 demonstrators to take the Carondelet presidential palace by force as Bucaram defied a growing chorus of calls for his removal.

Alarcon, the leader of the small centre-right Alfarist Radical Front, twice held the post of Congress president and was vice- president in charge in 1995 when then vice-president Alberto Dahik fled the country after being accused of corruption.
His party holds only three seats in the 82-member Congress.
Bucaram supporters accused Alacorn of being a spineless, opportunistic politician who reneged on his former ally to grab the presidency.
"Who is not loyal to a friend will not be loyal to the country," pro-Bucaram lawmaker Marco Proano said last week.
Critics at Congress nicknamed him "the dancer" for his apparent turncoat ability to support whoever is in power.
A graduate in political science from Quito Catholic University, Alarcon was born on April 14, 1947, in Quito. He is married to Lucia Pena Ochoa. They have three children.
